div.stage: Enter Roger Trusty to his lady all in a sweat with running: she seeing him come in such haste, cries out.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: O help me, help me, you merciful powers, to destroy me, and let me not outlive my husband.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: 'Tis like the gods will hear your prayers: for ten to one my master outlives you.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Why, is he alive?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Yes, and alive's like.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: What makes you sweat so?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: To bring you the good news of his well-being, and to prove the old proverb a liar, which says, bad news hath wings, and good news no legs.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Where did you meet your master?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: In Westminster-hall.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: How did he look?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Healthful and well.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Did he seem angry or pleased, merry or sad?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Why he neither seemed angry nor pleased, merry nor sad, which I wondered at: for in lawyer's courts, and places of judicature, I never saw any face but was clothed with a merry green countenance, or a sad black countenance, or a red choleric face, or a pale malicious face; but my master's face appeared like naked truth, and clean temperance, washed white with innocency; being plump with health, and smooth with plenty.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: But why did you leave him?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p:
Why he commanded me so to do, and to run every step, to tell you he was coming home, and I chose as the wisest to run, although
I sweat for it, than stay and have a broken head.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Well, I give you here a twenty-shilling-piece to dry your sweat with a cup of sack.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: May all my labours be rewarded thus.

sp.speaker: Maid Joan.
sp.p: I perceive you take the gift as a due reward, and not as my lady's bounty.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Hold your prating: what need we thank the gods, if saints merit heaven?

div.head: Scene 44.
div.stage: Enter the lady sprightly, and the lord widower her father.

sp.speaker: Lady sprightly.
sp.p: Sir, I desire you would not think me undutiful to ask you a question: for I hope I am not so much in your disfavour, as not to resolve me, since it is in your power.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: Well, what is't that you would know?

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Whether you are married, or not?

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: What if I am? Marriage is lawful.

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Yes sir, but I doubt whether it be honourable or not: for 'tis said you are married to my chambermaid Dol subtlety.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: Perchance I am.

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Then I desire your lordship will let me marry too.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: With all my heart, and I shall do my part towards thy marriage; but to whom would you be married?

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Your butler sir.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: Out upon thee base girl, would you marry a tapster?

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Why sir, a tapster is as good as a pisspot emptier; besides, they say you have done the fellow wrong: for she (They say) was his by promise, and if conscience hath right, he ought to have her; and perhaps, did not ambition come in the way, affection might prevail: wherefore to gratify him, you ought in justice to bestow me upon him.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: Well, because you shall not marry my butler, I will not marry your maid: for the truth is, I never had so low a thought. But let me tell you, it is in the way of disobedience to question a father's actions, and a presumption for a child to think their father is not wise enough to govern himself; besides, children were ingrateful to parents, to desire that from them, which they cannot, or will not keep to themselves, as neither to suffer a father to marry, or keep a mistress: do children think a father is bound to so many children, and no more?

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Sir, I dare answer for the part of children, that they would be well content that their father should have mistresses, but they would be unwilling and grieved that their fathers should be their mistress's slave, whereby they incaptivate their children, or ruin their estates.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: Well then inquire no more after any mistress I shall have, until you are incaptivated.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
